:''Multiboot redirects here. For the specification, see [[Multiboot Specification]].''
[[Image:Dual boot icon.svg|thumb|Artist's depiction of a boot manager's menu offering a choice between Microsoft Windows and Linux operating systems.]]<!-- Actual screenshots are in individual 2nd stage loaders' articles. -->
[[Image:Dual boot icon.svg|thumb|Artist's depiction of a boot manager's menu offering a choice between Microsoft Windows and Linux operating systems.]]<!-- Actual screenshots are in individual 2nd stage loaders' articles. -->
â
'''Multi boot''' or '''Multi booting''' is the act of installing multiple [[operating system]]s on a [[computer]], and being able to choose which one to [[Booting|boot]] when switching on the computer power. The program which makes dual booting possible is called a [[Booting#Second-stage boot loader|boot loader]].
+
'''Multi boot''' or '''Multi booting''' is the act of installing multiple [[operating system]]s on a [[computer]], and being able to choose which one to [[Booting|boot]] when switching on the computer power. The program which makes multi booting possible is called a [[Booting#Second-stage boot loader|boot loader]].
== Usage ==
== Usage ==
â
Dual booting is useful in many situations, such as those where several pieces of [[Computer software|software]] require different operating systems and cannot be run on a single system. A dual boot configuration will allow a user to use all of this software on one computer.
+
Multi booting is useful in many situations, such as those where several pieces of [[Computer software|software]] require different operating systems and cannot be run on a single system. A multi boot configuration will allow a user to use all of this software on one computer.
â
Another reason for setting up a dual boot system can be that one wants to investigate or test a new operating system without switching completely. Dual booting allows one to get to know the new system, configure all applications needed and migrate data before making the final step and removing the old operating system. For example, new users of [[Linux]] distributions migrating from the [[Microsoft Windows]] platform will usually dual boot, allowing them to try the new operating system without losing the functionality and preferences of their existing setup. This is often accomplished by using a [[Booting#Second-stage boot loader|boot loader]] that can boot more than one operating system, such as [[NTLDR]], [[LILO (boot loader)|LILO]], or [[GNU GRUB|GRUB]].
+
Another reason for setting up a multi boot system can be that one wants to investigate or test a new operating system without switching completely. Multi booting allows one to get to know the new system, configure all applications needed and migrate data before making the final step and removing the old operating system. For example, new users of [[Linux]] distributions migrating from the [[Microsoft Windows]] platform will usually multi boot, allowing them to try the new operating system without losing the functionality and preferences of their existing setup. This is often accomplished by using a [[Booting#Second-stage boot loader|boot loader]] that can boot more than one operating system, such as [[NTLDR]], [[LILO (boot loader)|LILO]], or [[GNU GRUB|GRUB]].
â
Dual booting can also aid [[software developer]]s where multiple operating systems are required for development or testing purposes. Having these systems on one machine can greatly reduce hardware costs. (However hardware costs are counterbalanced by system management costs, and the costs of the unavailability of the software that cannot be run at any given moment. Another solution to these problems is to use [[virtual machine]] software to emulate another computer from within the operating system of choice<sub>1</sub>.)
+
Multi booting can also aid [[software developer]]s where multiple operating systems are required for development or testing purposes. Having these systems on one machine can greatly reduce hardware costs. (However hardware costs are counterbalanced by system management costs, and the costs of the unavailability of the software that cannot be run at any given moment. Another solution to these problems is to use [[virtual machine]] software to emulate another computer from within the operating system of choice<sub>1</sub>.)
